importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 18, 2025, highlighting current developments in U.S. manufacturing under the context of trade policies and economic challenges, particularly related to President Donald Trump’s trade agenda.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Steinway & Sons began operations in 1873, marking the foundation of a century-long legacy in piano manufacturing that continues to influence modern U.S. manufacturing practices and worker skill preservation.

The article is set in the present day, emphasizing current challenges in American manufacturing, including tariffs, automation, labor shortages, and the viability of skilled craftsmanship in a modern economy.

keyTakeAways: Steinway & Sons, a company from the Gilded Age, continues to produce high-end pianos in the U.S. through skilled craftsmanship rather than mass production.
The company operates in Astoria, Queens, New York, and has maintained continuous production since 1873, only pausing during the Great Depression and World War II.
Building a Steinway grand piano takes 11 months and averages four to five pianos per day, emphasizing labor-intensive, high-quality craftsmanship.
Steinway charges prices from $90,000 to $200,000, enabling profitability despite high costs and limited output.
The company relies on domestic sourcing and skilled labor, with a particular need for Sitka spruce from Alaska, which grows slowly due to short growing seasons.
A shortage of skilled workers is a critical challenge, as these skills are not easily transferable or replicable in other locations.
President Donald Trump’s trade policies, including tariffs on steel, aluminum, and copper, have increased costs and created economic uncertainty, potentially harming broader manufacturing growth.
Despite the trade war, Steinway is insulated due to its focus on quality, innovation, and domestic manufacturing, showing a viable path for niche, high-value manufacturing in the U.S.
The article argues that traditional craftsmanship, once common in the Gilded Age, offers a sustainable model for U.S. manufacturing in an era of automation and global competition.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Steinway & Sons, a 150-year-old piano manufacturer based in Astoria, Queens, New York, exemplifies a rare and enduring model of U.S. manufacturing that thrives on skilled craftsmanship, quality, and premium pricing rather than mass production. Despite rising costs and the broader challenges of American manufacturing — including President Trump’s trade tariffs, automation, and labor shortages — Steinway has maintained operations through a focus on domestic sourcing, high-value products, and a consistent workforce of artisans. The company’s production of world-class pianos takes up to 11 months and involves only four to five pianos per day, relying on specialized skills that cannot be easily replicated elsewhere. While challenges such as the limited supply of Sitka spruce from Alaska and a shrinking pool of skilled workers remain, the company’s historical continuity and commitment to quality show a viable alternative to traditional, cost-driven manufacturing models. This case suggests that niche, high-value, handcrafted industries may offer a sustainable path for U.S. manufacturing in an era of automation and geopolitical uncertainty.
title: How a company from the Gilded Age could be the future of US manufacturing
